item.title: Gerrogate
item.description:
6:20 AM. With a brew in-hand I checked my emails before anything else, which was unusual, as that’s a habit I stopped long ago. So why I broke rank this random Wednesday morning I’ll never know. But it’s a decision that stole my day away.

“An email from Andrew McQuaid?”, I muttered mid-brew and half-asleep. “Sent at 2:20am? That’s a Euromail”, I said to Unibox, my email-client-of-choice. Despite the dots, and in light of my under-caffeinated state, I wasn’t prepared for the content of this “Mr Simon Gerrans” titled email.

“What the fuck? A ‘Cease and Desist’ letter?”

Confused by its vagueness and bemused by its poor punctuation, I read it again, twice. There was no confusing the complaint —it referred to a blurb I wrote just weeks ago— but there was much confusing the claim.

I refer you to […] the line “Sock Height is launching this July like Gerro on a Belgium berg.” This reference to “Gerro” infringes Mr Gerran’s intellectual property.

“Wow”, I said, yummying down on my second Scotch Finger of the day, “Are they taking the piss? Because that is not a line… that is word art. And if they think I’m just going to sit here and let them call it otherwise, they can goooo…..”

You see, I don’t care about Andrew. I was up on some cycling forums today, there was a kid couldn’t have been more than ten years old. He was asking a moderator if he had any other blurbs as good as SockHeight’s. That’s who I care about. The little kid who needs blurbs because his parent or guardian won’t let him read the excessive nonsense and strong repetitive content you and I read on cyclingnews.com.

So I’m issuing Andrew a Cease and Desist of my own: until such time that he and Trinity Sports Management rightfully refer to SockHeight blurbs as “Blurbs”, “Art”, or “Word art”, I’m not going to use that Gerro line on sockheight.com.

Actually I doubt I’d use it anyway… some guy called Lance is letting me use his name. So now Sock Height is officially…

Launching this July like Lance on L’Alp d’Huez

@SockHeight fine by me

— Lance Armstrong (@lancearmstrong) June 4, 2014

Got a #CeaseAndDesist from @simongerrans' lawyer for using the word "Gerro" on my website. Any legal advice anyone? pic.twitter.com/vdITOLSh12

— Sock Height (@SockHeight) June 3, 2014
